subsection.title: Using the Arithmetic of Derivatives Examples
subsection.p: In this section we illustrate the computation of derivatives using the arithmetic of derivatives Theorems, and. To make it clear which rules we are using during the examples we will note which theorem we are using:

Continuing on from the previous example, we can use the product rule and the previous result to compute
\diff{}{x} \big\{ x ( 4x + 7) \big\} &= x \cdot \diff{}{x} \{ 4x + 7 \} + (4x+7) \diff{}{x} \{ x \} & \text{PR}
&= x \cdot 4 + (4x+7) \cdot 1
&= 8x+7
where we have used the product rule PR with f(x) =x and g(x)=4x+7.

subsection.p: While the linearity theorem (Theorem ) is stated for a linear combination of two functions, it is not difficult to extend it to linear combinations of three or more functions as the following example shows.

example.title: Linearity of the derivative of three or more functions

subsection.p: Similarly, while the product rule is stated for the product of two functions, it is not difficult to extend it to the product of three or more functions as the following example shows.

example.title: Extending the product rule to more than two factors
example.p:
Once again, we'll start by generalising the product rule to three factors.
\amp\diff{}{x}\{F(x)\,G(x)\,H(x)\} =F'(x)\,G(x)\,H(x) +F(x)\, \diff{}{x}\{G(x)\,H(x)\}
& \hskip1in\text{by PR with} f(x)=F(x) \text{ and } g(x)=G(x)H(x)
&\hskip0.5in=F'(x)\,G(x)\,H(x) +F(x)\, \big\{G'(x)\,H(x)+G(x)\,H'(x)\big\}
&\hskip1in\text{by PR with} f(x)=G(x) \text{ and } g(x)=H(x)
This gives us a product rule for three factors, namely (just replacing upper case names by lower case names)
\diff{}{x}\{f(x)\,g(x)\,h(x)\} = f'(x)\,g(x)\,h(x) +f(x)\,g'(x)\,h(x)+f(x)\,g(x)\,h'(x)
Observe that when we differentiate a product of three factors, the answer is a sum of three terms and in each term the derivative acts on exactly one of the original factors. Just by repeating the above argument many times, we may generalise the product rule to give the derivative of a product of n factors, for any natural number n:
\diff{}{x}\{f_1(x)\,f_2(x)\,\cdots\,f_n(x)\} =\quad &f'_1(x)\,f_2(x)\,\cdots\,f_n(x)
+&f_1(x)\,f'_2(x)\,\cdots\,f_n(x)
&\qquad \qquad\vdots
+&f_1(x)\,f_2(x)\,\cdots\,f'_n(x)
We can also write the above as
\amp\diff{}{x}\{f_1(x)\,f_2(x)\,\cdots\,f_n(x)\}
\amp\hskip0.5in= \left[ \frac{f_1'(x)}{f_1(x)}+ \frac{f_2'(x)}{f_2(x)}+ \cdots +\frac{f_n'(x)}{f_n(x)} \right] \cdot f_1(x)\,f_2(x)\,\cdots\,f_n(x)

When we differentiate a product of n factors, the answer is a sum of n terms and in each term the derivative acts on exactly one of the original factors. In the first term, the derivative acts on the first of the original factors. In the second term, the derivative acts on the second of the original factors. And so on.

If we make f_1(x) = f_2(x) = \cdots = f_n(x) = f(x) then each of the n terms on the right hand side of the above equation is the product of f'(x) and exactly n-1 f(x)'s, and so is exactly f(x)^{n-1}\,f'(x). So we get the following useful result
\diff{}{x} f(x)^n &= n\cdot f(x)^{n-1} \cdot f'(x).

subsection.p: This last result is quite useful, so let us write it as a lemma for future reference.

statement.p:
Let n be a natural number and f be a differentiable function. Then
\diff{}{x} f(x)^n &= n\cdot f(x)^{n-1} \cdot f'(x).

subsection.p: This immediately gives us another useful result.

example.title: Derivative of x^n
example.p:
We can now compute the derivative of x^n for any natural number n. Start with Lemma and substitute f(x)=x and f'(x)=1:
\diff{}{x}x^n &= n \cdot x^{n-1} \cdot 1 = n\, x^{n-1}

subsection.p: Again this is a result we will come back to quite a few times in the future, so we should make sure we can refer to it easily. However, at present this statement only holds when n is a positive integer. With a little more work we can extend this to compute x^q where q is any positive rational number and then any rational number at all (positive or negative). So let us hold off for a little longer. Instead we can make it a lemma, since it will be an ingredient in quite a few of the examples following below and in constructing the final corollary.

statement.p:
Let n be a positive integer then
\diff{}{x} x^n = n x^{n-1}

md.intertext: by Lemma, once with n=3, and once with n=5

example.title: Derivative of product of polynomials
Derivative of a cube-root
example.p:
In this example, we'll use a little trickery to find the derivative of \root{3}\of{x}. The trickery consists of observing that, by the definition of the cube root,
x= \left(\root{3}\of{x}\right)^3.
Since both sides of the expression are the same, they must have the same derivatives:
\diff{}{x}\left\{x\right\} = \diff{}{x}\left(\root{3}\of{x}\right)^3.
We already know by Theorem that
\diff{}{x}\big\{x\big\}=1
and that, by Lemma with n=3 and f(x)=\root{3}\of{x},
\diff{}{x}\big(\root{3}\of{x}\big)^3 = 3\ \big(\root{3}\of{x}\big)^2\cdot \diff{}{x}\big\{\root{3}\of{x}\big\} = 3\,x^{2/3}\cdot \diff{}{x}\big\{\root{3}\of{x}\big\}.
Since we know that \diff{}{x}\left\{x\right\} = \diff{}{x}\left(\root{3}\of{x}\right)^3, we must have
1=3x^{2/3}\cdot \diff{}{x}\big\{\root{3}\of{x}\big\}
which we can rearrange to give the result we need
\diff{}{x}\big\{\root{3}\of{x}\big\} &=\tfrac{1}{3} x^{-2/3}

example.title: Derivative of a negative rational power of x

subsection.p: Note that we have found, in Examples , and , the derivative of x^a for any rational number a, whether 0, positive, negative, integer or fractional. In all cases, the answer is

statement.p:
Let a be a rational number, then
\diff{}{x} x^a = a x^{a-1}

subsection.p: We shall show, in Example, that the formula \diff{}{x} x^a = a x^{a-1} in fact applies for all real numbers a, not just rational numbers.

ul.li:
As we seen before, the best strategy for dealing with nasty expressions is to break them up into easy pieces. We can think of f(x) as the fivefold product
f(x)=f_1(x)\cdot f_2(x)\cdot f_3(x)\cdot \frac{1}{f_4(x)}\cdot \frac{1}{f_5(x)}
with
f_1(x)\amp=\sqrt{x}-1\amp f_2(x)\amp=2-x\amp f_3(x)\amp=1-x^2
f_4(x)\amp=\sqrt{x}\amp f_5(x)\amp=3+2x

By now, the derivatives of the f_j's should be easy to find:
f'_1(x)\amp=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}\amp f'_2(x)\amp=-1\amp f'_3(x)\amp=-2x
f'_4(x)\amp=\frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}}\amp f'_5(x)\amp=2
